reviewText:
Played since Closed Beta. Have a max lv toon and here are the basics about this game

Pros:

- Aesthetically pleasing. the game looks nice and has a large variety of monsters

- Engaging combat. Its a lot of fun and quite challenging in later levels

- Plenty of Variety in the game as well

- Dozens upon dozens of awesome mounts!

Cons:

-Horribly Unbalanced. Cleric is god in PvE. they have the highest damage out of anyone by an absurd amount AND they are the best healers in the game. And certain builds for PVP just laugh at everyone else since they can 1 shot other players with spammable skills. there is no balance nor will it be a thing anytime soon.

-Daily Limits kill the variety. The game has a ton of variety but because of the daily limit ON EVERYTHING *there is 1000 mob kill limit on a map and 3-5 instance limit* it makes the variety" feel a lot smaller then it really is.

-Incredibly boring grind for last quarter of the game. Do you like killing about 30 bosses and 1000+ enemies and doing about 50 quests for a whopping 10% xp? well thats too bad. since if you want to lv in a reasonable amount of time thats how your daily grind will be.

-Need to abuse the Auction House or Pay real money to be able to afford half the features. A lot of the stuff on here is not cheap and sadly quests/mobs don't give nearly enough to afford any of them. So you are left praying that one of the bosses you kill for your daily limit drop a rare drop which you can sell for 3x what you will earn doing every non repeatable quest in the game

-End game PvP is awful if you do not play hardcore everyday/pay real money for upgrades. there will be many times where you join PVP only to have your entire group 1 shotted the second they pop out of the teleporter with pretty much nothing you can do about it.

-Stuck with starter pet foreeeever. By the time I hit lv cap i wasn't even halfway to unlocking a different class with your little pet. so unless you pay real money don't read the pet customization because that will be dissappointment.



overall its a really cute fun action MMO. but while it is chock full of what seem like awesome features the more you play the more you realize that almost all features are average/below average at best and its entire package just comes to a MMO that tries to do a bunch of stuff but doesn't do it any better then many of the MMO's out there"

reviewText:
Great game, 250+ hours off steam and still not bored.


Would be even better if these things were removed COMPLETELY not increased.

- 1000 kill limit (dragomon eggs still drop but material that are required to level guild do not.)

- 25 Hunt mission limit (barely enough to clear one bounty board.)

- 30 HL Bounties Limit (You are forced prioritize skill points, fishing, Hunters or a little of each)

- 3-5 Instance entry limit (once you hit these you only have two options, log out till reset or collect dragomon.)

I would also like to add these limits are mostly anti-botting messures (that imo, increase the amount of bots, 1 bot hits the limit 2 more take its place.) which makes it feel like you're being punished as a group for the actions of an individual.

Now some of the good stuff.

- Tons Dragomon to collect and breed for rare and exotic looking varients.

- Good daily event list, rewarding Loyalty Points, Lucky boxes, EXP badges, Adv Evo Scrolls and Loot Charms.

- Almost everything in the item mall is available in the loyalty shop. def not pay2win.

- Never have to worry about breaking a sword that cost 300g and days of farming to craft while upgrading. always a plus when it comes to mmos. (imo)

- Decent action combat and pvp battles.

- Pretty good party system featuring server wide recruit broadcast and the ability to warp all members to you regardless of channel.

- Great boss battles, some requiring you to run and destroy objects that are giving the boss almost inpenatrable defense and damaging auras all while dodging attacks that take half your health in one hit.

- Leveling is extremely easy. anyone who says otherwise is not even qualified to be a casual.

- Hunters Archive, the ultimate end game goal, collect everything to earn an epic mount, title, hall of fame on the website and about 1500$ in fortune gems and upgrade items.

anyways I have heroic bosses to fight and can't waste anymore time on this review, (despite all the limits) its a great game try it.


ps. abandon your level grinding mindset, do the main and side quest, then before you know it you will be 2 levels away from max without even trying or using EXP boosters. GL

reviewText:
Dragomon Hunter is a mix out of the popular Aura Kingdom formula put together with Pokemon and Dragon Hunter (though it does not have too much in common with DH or Pokemon other than gotta collect them all)

The Game is incredible addicting and fun to play. It is an Action MMORPG with lots of movement needed to survive.. especially as cloth user.
Their classbalancing is quite okay and cloth users can gather more stats due to the low deffence, which results in some leather users going clotharmor for more burstdmg.

Pay2Win?:
NO... while Aeria Games games are likely to be p2w this one realy is not.. their cashshop is quite expensive but you can get everything realy cheap for a few gold or in their gamblebox/Gamblegame (Falcon Fortune).. a role only costs 30/40g and you can get them through events, buying, dailymissionboxes and co.. a good Falconboard can give you even more rolls than you invested... I ended up having casharmor, mount, wings and a few bags for solely 2$ (and those points i even had from other games left.. so basically no money spent)   cashshop worth over 200$ for simply a few rolls without having to pay anything.. could have bought the rolls with gold aswell..
(Gold in this game is like gold in most other mmos like DN/WoW.. a propper endgame item can give 20k++ aka enough rolls for going all out...)

PvP:
Their Arena is somewhat ballanced for max level but totaly unbalanced for lower lvls as you get matched together with max lvl (50) players arround lvl 40 onwards and they can pretty much onehit you. But this is negotiable as you don't have to play PvP before max level you know?
Besides those flaws there is a PvP Arena where you use your Dragomons to fight and this one is balanced whatever level you are.. also the Battleground (up to 500vs500 fractionpvp) is playable with lower levels.

PvE:
There is a daily limit for Daily/Boardquests (30) and Huntingquests (25) [TIPP: Always max those out and once you get to a mainquest where you have to do one of those, it will reset the whole limit automatically]

The leveling part goes smooth until arround lvl 37/38 where you have to do a few dungeonruns (or wait for dailyreset) to level up to 40 to continue with the mainquest.
From lvl 44 onwards there will be another gap until lvl 50 where you have to level without Mainquest, however Ranchbosses give an incredible amount of extra exp and together with the 30 dailys and 25 Huntmissionslimit you can get at least 1-1.5 lvls a day, making the leveling feel rewarding.

Party Dungeons realy are something for a party.. A level 40+ can hardly solo a lvl 28 partydungeon with more than 1 Dragomonboss (Netherrealms) alone due to lack of hp.  Therefore it stays challending.
There is a difference between Normal" and "Hard" dungeons - hard are realy hardcore.

You can get Dragomons by grinding mobs or doing Dungeons

So far, I like it. Aeria Games doesn't usually impress me, but that's not the case here.

I had a few rough patches at the start, but the game jumpstarts quickly. It is a genuine amount of fun and I think I'll play it a little more often.

Dragomon Hunter allows the player to take on a role of a warrior whose job is to kill monsters. That's it. However, this is much cooler than it sounds. With 4 starter classes, players can choose from the getgo, what their fighting style is. Although, you cannot change this once selected, so choose your class wisely.

The hunting itself is some great fun too. All of the monsters have an interesting design, and you have the ability to unlock ridable versions of these monsters. So if you grow attached to a specific beast, rest assured that you will soon be riding off into the sunset on their back, with a bit of effort.

This game is very cool, though I do have some gripes. Personally, I don't enjoy the friend system. Partying up with friends is fun, but you are never sure how long it will take to find them, should they go astray. That being said, a system in which friends can teleport to their buddy's side would be a welcome addition.

Also, the limited classes and the inability to have multiple classes on a save file are a bit annoying, but I get the point that you are one affiliation per save file.

Final Verdict: An MMORPG is a difficult game to market these days, but this one brings something fun to the table, and I can easily see myself playing it more

Final Mark: 3/5

Gameplay

reviewText:
Once upon a time, in an age before Pokemon, mons and humans did not live in peace.  The threat the various mons posed could not be understated - a herd could destroy villages and damage cities!  Of course, humanity, being the benevolent heroes that we are, devised new and better ways to beat the mons into submission.  The future is uncertain, but it will be bright.  I say this after having beaten a wierd dragon-walrus hybrid into a stupor and having intimidated it into being my mount, while having defeated another dragon-walrus and used it to impregnate my sword with the ability to better defeat other mons.  My name is Aurron (because I'm original), and I am a Samurai who owns things.

Dragonmon Hunter is Pokemon meets World of Warcraft, with emphasis on and the problems conferred by the latter.  It's a cute, brightly-colored MMORPG that has some great ideas.  For instance, every monster in the game is a prospecitve mount.  Every monster can be hunted for 'Dragocite' gems that you can use to customize gear.  Most monsters' drops are actually useful!  And best of all, few weapons are shorter than 125% of your character's height!

What's to love/not to love?  Well, I'll tell you!

What Works
First things first - the hand-holdiness of the game.  While I understand why other reviewers are leery/just plain sick of it, I actually found some of the 'hand-holdy' features to be useful, because I have time limitations and often skip quest text.  That being said, there are problems that I will get to in the What Doesn't Work section.  The point is, most of the hand-holdy features are annoying early on, but properly used they can improve the experience, which is always nice.

The game is Free-to-Play, yet, I think it handles this very well compared to other F2P titles.  There are some pay-to-win elements; collecting stuff provides passive stats, so not buying custom outfits or weapon costumes will mean that your stats are lower than a buy-hard.  However, the game doesn't require you to buy anything - most games where you don't buy, you pay for it by taking longer to do everything.  This game, you mostly face bag space limitations, which is omnipresent in MMORPG literature.  I wish more F2P titles handled the business model as well as this one.  I might actually A) keep playing, and B) buy something (probably some 10-slot bags) as a result!  Who'd've thought!?

So, I finally get to the graphics, which are really well-done, and most of all, well-optimized.  My somewhat old PC handles the game with few lagspikes, and with some features like Depth of Field and multisampling turned on.  It's nice to play a game that isn't too taxing on a somewhat old PC for a change - and, a game that looks good doing it!

More mechanically, character moves.  You have exactly eigh moves for your class, which you can customize.  You can customize further after Lv.20 by choosing a secondary weapon that changes your moves.  For instance, my Mage, PrettyPwny is a nuker with a staff, but instead becomes a controlling-supporter with a War Horn (which also makes her attacks musically themed, to boot.)  There aren't too many 'strategic cooldown' moves unlike other MMORPGs out there, and I find it nice that all abilities are directly useful.  Another great idea.

While there are more, the last one I want to draw attention to is the PvE experience.  There are some really satisfying missions in this game, and even more satisfying boss fights.  While they're nothing too hard (don't stand in stuff on the ground), they feel great due to tight controls, interesting if relatively unvaried monster designs, and making the fights beatable, but requiring the player to pay attention.  The game provides potential difficulty that is mitigated by practicing paying attention.  Skill > Gear...usually.  I find that a really great principle for a game you play with others.

What Doesn't Work
Before I get into this, something I want to note is that all my 'what doesn't work' notes are the 'dark side' of things I noted that do work.  This game is notable because it has generally great ideas underlying it.  However, the high-level problem this game has was something I said: this game has all of the problems that World of Warcraft and Pokemon have.

First, hand-holdiness.  I'm OK with the hand-holdiness because that's not the core problem this game has.  The real problem, is that this game throws stuff at you - big numbers, lots of text, changes where you are and what you're doing nearly constantly.  You never have time to really get a good footing with this game.  The reason the hand-holdiness is there is to make the game more manageable, which it does.  That is not a good thing, though.

Fix: I suggest the developers pay attention to the early experience, particularly in 'the noob zone.'  Let players have a few more opportunities to fight monsters early on and become familiar with the controls and interface.  This is something World of Warcraft did well, actually - all of the starter zones can be completed within 30-45 minutes if you don't know what you're doing.  The point of those zones and the pace of levelups is to let the player feel alright with the controls and UI, before throwing execution challenges at them.

Speaking of UI, it does not scale well, physically or intellectually.  Good UIs work well 'small', if you consider 1366x768 small.  I don't think the developers of this work do - it seems like it would handle better at any larger resolution, but bigger resolutions would be better.  As far as 'intellectually', let's be honest - there is a lot of useless stuff on-screen.  Sure, you can hide some things, but early on you see a lot of things you just can't make use of.  While this is standard for the MMORPG genre, it's disappointing in a game that otherwise puts effort into accessibility.

Fix: Consider your UI design more carefully and the concept of 'progressive disclosure' - don't show things until they're needed.  Final Fantasy XIV does this really well, and would be a good role-model for this young MMORPG to take cues from.  Physically, redesign the UI for a smaller form-factor, probably 800x600 resolution - if you can't play this game on a single monitor, windowed, while reading the wiki or reddit, you've got usability problems.

As far as business models, the 'pay-to-win' stat boosts being conferred for collecting things you can only get via paying, I find to be a Very Bad Thing™.  Your business model is so well-concieved and even-handed, that conveying stat gains for buy-only costumes comes off probably exactly as you intended - something you think is harmless, but due to the fact that it's a key consideration in min-maxing, will eventually earn you 'pay-to-win' accusations, because we gamers are rational, forgiving folk.

To fix this, remove stat bonuses from the collection system for buy-only costumes and weapon costumes.  Offer these as decorative things are intended - an inherent way to assert your own in-game identity, not another thing to min-max.  Alternatively, why not sell the game for a flat price and give us some things off-the-bat?

Lastly, the PvE experience.  This game starts off with a lot of instanced bits to make things easier to understand, which I applaud.  What I don't applaud is how shallow the 'exploration' maps are.

Fix: More exploration!  Gotta beat 'em all!

The TL;DR
This game is a good, if inexpert, MMORPG.  It has room to grow, but it's far from terrible.  The ratings of 6/10 I find a little low - I'd rate this 7.5/10.  If the dev team works on the UI and presentation, and removes the opportunity for 'pay-to-win' whining, this game can get the better marks it deserves.  It's enjoyable, a definite thumbs-up, and worth your time to play.  Do so!

reviewText:
There is so much wrong and so much they tried to make right, but went wrong.  I'll start with the biggest things:  The monster hunter style gameplay and using the dragomon to fight other dragomon.

The monster hunter gameplay is somewhat there, monsters strike anything in front of it, and so do you in melee range.  The main problem with this is that when you attack your rooted in place and does not give you enough time to get away from being attacked, and right around the 30s lvl, that is an important thing cause the mobs start dealing quite abit of damage that can stack quickly.

The using dragomon to fight other dragomon (as advertised in their video) is not even possible and you can only use your monster pets in battlegrounds after getting an extreamly high rating.  Even using them is risky as when you die using them they permamently die, which throws all the hard work you put into them away.

There are some good things I like about this game though, the fishing aqua lords quick time events are really nice way to keep you on your toes.  When you do get a chance to ride monsters they are pretty epic feeling (with the exception of 1-2).  I also like the idea of aquiring titles and leveling proffesions giving you stat rewards.

There is one other main problem that this game shares with Aura Kingdom (made from same company) and that is so much daily stuff to do that it litterally takes hours to get threw.  For example a lvl 29 character (me) took about 4-5 hours to do all dailies available, which is INSANE!!!  There is the argument that you do not have to do them, but to get the stat boosts to keep up with higher leveled areas makes it more manditory than it should be.

All in all, I feel like this game is still incomplete, like it is in it's alpha stages.  I really wanted to like this game it had alot of promise, but there is just so much negative that I cannot overlook.

reviewText:
On the outside this looks like a childish and possibly p2w game. It's not. The only thing childish about it is the Chibi design. It includes solid and responsive combat that gets increasingly difficult and dynamic, many dungeons with legitimate mmo themed mechanics, a large variety of classes and monsters (each of whom you can get as a drop to ride as a mount, tame, and make pets out of).  There is a wealth of cool gear and character cuztomizations as well. A lot of which is accessible without heading to the cash shop which is IN NO WAY PAY TO WIN.  The cash shop itself is great and has easily obtained in game points you can gain and use to buy most of the items as well.  If you have the time you can grind, if you have to work a lot you can buy the costumes its a fair and non game breaking cash shop as the combat itself is satisfying.  The community can be all over the place like any MMO but the game itself does not take itself particularly seriously and this leads to some laidback adventures with friends.  One thing that holds many people back from enjoying the game is the limit of dungeons and quests per day.  I personally find this to be a great way to get players to gain experience thrugh the many activities in the game as there are are more than a few!  If you go into this game and end up saying theress not a lot to do: Ask for some help because you're missing something. The game has such a high focus on detail you'll be blown away. Its easy to see the developers were thinking about player convenience (I.E. You will never get lost as you can click you quest objective to run there.) The game also inclues some great rpg aspects as well like stat points, some surprisingly good story writing, dialogue, and flavor text.  I encourage you to try this game even if you feel apprehensive at first look as it can actually be quite satisfying without spending a single dime (though you'll probably want to support the game once you have as much fun as I have). 50 hours so far and planning to keep playing as my feel good mmo alongside some other more adult themed ones!

TLDR: Pros and Cons

Pros:
-Multiple ways to play the game: Action mmo, Classic mmo a la guild wars 1, hybrid action/classic, and top down click to move a la Diablo. Even has controller support with a run to quest button.
-Solid Combat
-Many Classes
-Stylized and Enjoyable Artsyle
-Monster Hunter meets Pokemon
-Rewarding although simple crafting
-Well done Jap Voice overs
-Strong/Classic RPG aspects
-Good dialogue
-Family Friendly

Cons:
-Gold must be spent wisely
-Activity Caps bad for people who like playing 1 character only
-Bots are pretty obvious (keep to themselves only affect the economy really)
-A couple of irritating quests that you need to do to get rid of
-Time will fly by way too fast
-The cash shop stuff is super cool and you'll want to spend money (the in game stuff is just as cool but if you're a spender beware...)
-NEED MOAR DRAGOMON NAO (gotta catch em all right?)

After 20 minutes I already knew what this was.

Take a look at the publisher.  Aeria Games.  They publish all the garbageware MMO's from Japan, Korea and China.  These garbageware MMO's cost the developer only a few million dollars to produce most likely but rake in 10 times that in microtransactions.

Don't take my cynisism as to mean I don't enjoy this game so far.  It is mindless button mashing using a tab free targeting system.  You can use tab target, but don't necessarily need to.  There is no auto attack. You will be mashing the 1, 2, and 3 keys nonstop.

As for the aethetic....it's anime characters in a childish motif.  They have huge heads and wild hair.  If this turns you off then DONT download this, because it's everywhere.  The colors are vibrant however and the cell shaded graphics do have a certain appeal when they aren't bombarding you in the face.

As for these standard Asian MMO's, you can click the quest text to auto run to that location.  Most of the Asian MMO's have this mechanic.  This makes the game a mindless grind fest from one quest to another.  Just click the quest and you ride there with no input from the user.   This game is the epitome of casual.  Once you get to the quest area, there are mobs randomly placed around.  Nothing new here.  We've seen this all before in COUNTLESS MMo's.

I'm still playing the game because it's a nice time waster and the microtransactions aren't shoved down your throat.  I gave it a thumbs up because it's not a terrible game.  You get what you pay for.  This is a standard freemium game that can cost you thousands of dollars if you let the game inside your brain.  It is certainly playable without paying a cent.  From what I've read, there are no pay wall's for content.  So take from this what you will.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Dragonmon Hunter is a game where you, a hero of your own, are in a massive world full of other players (The community is not active in chat and such, though.).

My opinion on the game is very well clear, it is a fantastic game. The fighting style is amazing. It has great mechanics, easy controls, and the sensitivity option was handy due to the fact that I am very slick and need precise and fast reaction to help me out in combat, weather it'd be a dragon, a reptite, a baby, or another player.

The storyline is quite quirky, but also makes me giggle from time to time. The dialogue is very bland and more of it is explainig what to do then an actual story, It is still very cute. (I have not FINISHED THE STORY)


The graphics are the cutest part. They kept me in a mystical and fantasy world where I could imagine fighting these beastly dragons. The art style was very anime, but kept and medival and magical feel to my eyes. Every second of the game I was glazing my way through glourious maps, stopping to admire the scenery that the developers have put together, the lighting was just on spot.

And don't get me started on the character design, because all the characters are adorable little beings if I say so myself. You have the option to pay for cosmetics, but you don't have to, you can earn them in-game, and good looking weapons.

The whole concept is like any other mmorpg. Go around, kill things, collec tthe stuff, deliver it, visit places, do it again. What can I say? Classic is always good, and I love me some classic MMORPG style action!

The game is completely free to play, but you of course have the option to pay for perks. But not at all do you need to do this.

I'd rate this game 9/10, mainly because of the storyline portion.

reviewText: Hey guys, you ever wanted to play a crappy rip-off on Capcom's Monster Hunter?? Oh but it has Pokemon things too?? You don't do that!!! You just don't do that!!! Monster Hunter is a fun game because it makes you feel powerful and the monsters are memorable and fun to fight, each with their own moves and tactics to take them down using you wit, your weapon's skills, and the environment around you. Pokemon is fun because it gives you lovable characters you can use to fight with as well as clever movesets to outsmart your opponent. This game doesn't have that. It has an isometric view with weapons that ALMOST come close to the Monster Hunter weapons (Being a lancer in Monster Hunter, I thought I'd try the lance guy, but he was so fast! And you can't sheild and attack at the same time! I know, they're different games and stuff, but COME ON!!! If you're gonna make a game based off of a game that's making MEGA bank in Japan, then at least copy the moves and the weapons right. And don't try to tell me it's not based off of them because partsw of the titles of the original games are in the title of this one.), a total lack of environment usage, and what basically amounts to Black Dragon, Red Dragon, Purple Dragon, Cyan Dragon, Mauve Dragon, obviously I'm making stuff up at this point but you get it, monsters that aren't memorable. I gave this game the benefit of the doubt, but it was no better than I expected. The Practice Dummies were even shaped like the Great Jaggi, and upon further playing, I discovered that a retextured Great Jaggi is in the game, but it's called a Sunburst Raptite. Don't waste your time with this game unless you're trying to hype yourself up for when you've saved up enough for a 3DS, Monster Hunter, and Pokemon.

reviewText:
Dragomon Hunter is one of the most boring and uninteresting games due to it's automatic click and go system where you are automatically taken to the next quest objective, if you're lost or the map is confusing to new players this is extremely helpful, however if you can easily abuse this system and almost feels like you're watching someone play rather than doing it yourself.

The combat is dull, slow, clunky, and doesn't hold any sort of challenge as I found myself collecting health pots at the start of the game and never having to even think about using them.

The armour system is absolutely pointless as you equip new armour to increase stats they hold no sort of customization or appearance changes whatsoever, to change the appearance you are given outfits as rewards which aren't the worst things to look at, which brings us onto the graphics.

The game is actually very pleasant to look at and the monsters are designed well and look like they should hold some sort of challenge, unfortunately that isn't the case as I was killing bosses as if they were ordinary mobs.
I did notice lighting bugs at times but nothing major.

Overall, I find it hard to even call this a game, it feels like some ones gone onto a anime forum and taken some ones awfully written lore and put a few basic 3D graphics to it with some clunky camera controls and set you on your way.
The feeling of collecting the 'dragomon' isn't there, as it doesn't feel like an achievement that you've killed it, it's more a way of showing other players how much time you've wasted on this game.

2/10 Playing Uno with myself would be more entertaining

reviewText:
From playing WoW for many years and Monsterhunter this game is a nice mix of both worlds.

Great game if you are looking for a F2P casual game with nice graphics and easy navigation. You can just click on your current objective and you will autorun to the location. I find it a nice change of pace compared to any new MMO where you can get lost VERY easily and then give up because you have lost interest trying to find 1 NPC in a crowded city.

Pros:
-Controls are easy to learn
-Graphics and design are sweet
-Easy naviagation (just click on your quest objective and you will autorun there)
-ALOT of things to do
-Fun and challenging
-Enough bag space (for now)
-All runs are instanced so game is very quick to pick up and put down (no running around looking for stuff and wasting time)
-Not centered around Microtransactions


Cons:
-Some might find the autorun feature too easy, not appealing
-Anime style might not appeal to most

This game is a Monster Hunger clone, right down to how the rare monsters appear (if you play monster hunter you will know when you see it).

I would highly recommend TRYING this game, I was skeptical at first but I am hooked and am excited to what the game is like at max level.

reviewText:
Veredict about Dragomon Hunter
Torturous to keep playing

* You constantly have to craft new equipments because your equips gets outdated
and very often runs out of coins, meaning that you will be unable to craft equips.
* Your companion also will need you to craft his equips to make him tougher, meaning that you will have to raid more zones.
* Hunting board quests does not seems to be repeatable, meaning that you will not be able to make coins with it.
* Your inventory will often be full of materials because of doing several missions at the same time, and you will often ask yourself what items to discard because you will certainly not know what item is usefull for something (but as a little cheat, just see the name of the craft set the item creates and then check on the craft master, at the item description).
* You are introduced to your companions having more classes but there is no way you can change your class, unless you want to repeat a same dungeon around over 100 times because beside you need to loot 4 tickets to be able to access the said dungeon, the items necessary to unlock the class of the companion drops very rarelly.
In my experience for example, I got introduce to new companion class, had 10/60 progress to learn the class, during around 6 or 7 ticket dungeon runs, I were able to get 1 book that increased the progress of one of the 3 classes the companion can get in 1 point, meaning that I would need to collect and use more 49 of the same book.
* Fishing, is pointless, the fishs only give a buff that lasts a few minutes, and you can only use one fish at a time.
* All items, or almost, I'm sure that almost items in the game only gives 1 silver when sold, includding equips, meaning that if you plan on farming equips to make coins, you will have to rethink that idea.
* Ranch system is confusing, you place dragomon mounts in there, just so they do... Nothing, they seems to contribute in nothing.

I does not know how I survived 5 hours playing that game, but I hope I does not have a nightmare due to this
Also, another fact, the game have unskipable cutscenes, being that the true intro of the game only comes at level 18, aka after 4 or 5 hours of gameplay.

The leveling is fast until level 15, then it suddenly slowdown like as it takes ages to level up.
The black screens are back, but they are not as frequent as on Aura Kingdom, but they are still annoying.
The Aura Kingdom's and Eden Eternal's quest that requires you to buy a cash item in order to complete it is also in this game.
